Title: Designing Your Life: Build a Life that Works for You
Author: Bill Burnett
My Review:
The Big Idea:

"â€œWhen designing your life, you start with who you are (chapters 1, 2, and 3). Then you have lots of ideas (rather than wait and wait to have the idea of the century) and you try things out by doing them (chapters 4, 5, and 6), and then you make the best choice you can (chapter 8). As you do all this, including making choices that set you on one path for a number of years, you grow various aspects of your personality and identity that are nurtured and called upon by those experiencesâ€”you become more yourself. In this way, you energize a very productive cycle of growth, naturally evolving from being, to doing, to becoming. Then it all repeats, as the more-like-you version of you (your new being) takes the next step of doing, and so it goes.â€ù

Stanford professors in the Design Department teach the most popular class at Stanford: Designing Your Life. This is their book with the same goal."
Â 
Highlights:
Â 
â€œFor most people, passion comes after they try something, discover they like it, and develop mastery - not before. To put it more succinctly: passion is the result of a good life design, not the cause.â€ù

"
â€œThese are all gravity problemsâ€”meaning they are not real problems. Why? Because in life design, if itâ€™s not actionable, itâ€™s not a problem. Letâ€™s repeat that. If itâ€™s not actionable, itâ€™s not a problem. Itâ€™s a situation, a circumstance, a fact of life. It may be a drag (so to speak), but, like gravity, itâ€™s not a problem that can be solved.â€ù

Gravity problems: if itâ€™s not actionable, itâ€™s not a problem. Two types of gravity problems: totally un-actionable and functionally un-actionable. Either way, focus on finding actionable solutions to actionable problems"

"â€œThatâ€™s why you start where you are. Not where you wish you were. Not where you hope you are. Not where you think you should be. But right where you are.â€ù


â€œAs a life designer, you need to embrace two philosophies: 1. You choose better when you have lots of good ideas to choose from. 2. You never choose your first solution to any problem.â€ù
"


Actionable Items:

"Health/Work/Play/Love dashboard:

Consider updating Todoist to align with this framework?
Align with 1 Big Thing idea and make sure there's something going for each at all times?

"

"Re-read/do the exercises in the book:
Health/Work/Play/Love dashboard. For each area:
1. Mark where you are (0 to Full)
2. Mark where you would be if you made an incremental improvement (0 to Full)
3. Review what incremental change you could make, and how you could pilot for 2 weeks.

Good Time Journal, work view and life view exercise / reflections, & other exercises

Use of ideation tools to help come up with better ideas"

"Build an intentional menâ€™s group / Group of friends help you design your life

Identifying your team: supporters, players who are the active participants in your life design project, intimates, the team , etc.

Donâ€™t start with the problem start with people, start with empathy

The question is what do you want to be to grow up. The question is what do you want to grow into?

Connect who you are, what you believe, and what you were doing."

Other Notes & Takeaways:
"There's lots to recommend, but the book itself is very focused on discussing career design, and is rather lacking in useful exercises. It may have been an artifact of listening to the audiobook, but I listened intently but didn't finish with any form of life design plan. Just some useful thoughts.

I'd say it looses a star for not being the 5 star book it could be."

Audiobook

Highlights:
Â 
"â€œNo one tells you itâ€™s all about to change, to be taken away. Thereâ€™s no proximity alert, no indication that youâ€™re standing on the precipice. And maybe thatâ€™s what makes tragedy so tragic. Not just what happens, but how it happens: a sucker punch that comes at you out of nowhere, when youâ€™re least expecting it. No time to flinch or brace.â€ù
"

"â€œImagine youâ€™re a fish, swimming in a pond. You can move forward and back, side to side, but never up out of the water. If someone were standing beside the pond, watching you, youâ€™d have no idea they were there. To you, that little pond is an entire universe. Now imagine that someone reaches down and lifts you out of the pond. You see that what you thought was the entire world is only a small pool. You see other ponds. Trees. The sky above. You realize youâ€™re a part of a much larger and more mysterious reality than you had ever dreamed of.â€ù
"




Actionable Items:







Other Notes & Takeaways:
Pulp fiction in the Stephen King vein. Good start, well paced middle, soft ending. Feels like it could have used some strong editing/rewrites to tighten up the narrative to go with the excellent premise.

Title: Between the World and Me
Author: Ta-Nehisi Coates
My Review:
The Big Idea:

"Public letter to his son from an educated black man about the trials and tribulations of living in modern America, with insights into the life of minorities (and African-Americans in particular) and the realities of â€œraceâ€ù. This is a book full of quotes. Lots of poetic illustrations of the realities, but I didnâ€™t find many ideas for progress or future healing.

I see parallels to my personal criticisms of Sociology: â€œHereâ€™s how the world is screwed up. No idea how to fix it.â€ù"
Â 
Highlights:
Â 
â€œI would not have you descend into your own dream. I would have you be a conscious citizen of this terrible and beautiful world.â€ù

â€œYou are growing into consciousness, and my wish for you is that you feel no need to constrict yourself to make other people comfortable.â€ù

"â€œOne cannot, at once, claim to be superhuman and then plead mortal error. I propose to take our countrymenâ€™s claims of American exceptionalism seriously, which is to say I propose subjecting our country to an exceptional moral standard.â€ù

â€œNot being violent enough could cost me my body. Being too violent could cost me my body. We could not get out.â€ù

â€œHere is what I would like for you to know: In America, it is traditional to destroy the black bodyâ€”it is heritage. Enslavement was not merely the antiseptic borrowing of laborâ€”it is not so easy to get a human being to commit their body against its own elemental interest. And so enslavement must be casual wrath and random manglings, the gashing of heads and brains blown out over the river as the body seeks to escape. It must be rape so regular as to be industrial. There is no uplifting way to say this. I have no praise anthems, nor old Negro spirituals. The spirit and soul are the body and brain, which are destructibleâ€”that is precisely why they are so precious. And the soul did not escape. The spirit did not steal away on gospel wings. The soul was the body that fed the tobacco, and the spirit was the blood that watered the cotton, and these created the first fruits of the American garden. And the fruits were secured through the bashing of children with stovewood, through hot iron peeling skin away like husk from corn.â€ù "


Actionable Items:

No idea





Other Notes & Takeaways:
This was a prodfoundly poetic book, and beautiful, if tragic, letter from a father to son. I just wish it included some broader context for the readers who are not the son about how to bridge the gao from here to the there of a truly healthy and fair society.

-Providing honest data
-Allowing us to drill into small subsets of data
-Allowing us to do many causal experiments
"
Â 
Highlights:
Â 
Data can be used to find incredibly interesting and noble things from surprising sources. For example using Google searches to find interesting informationâ€™s about sex preferences etc.

Curse of dimensionality: looking at so many dimensions that you are guaranteed a false positive

DoppelgÃ_nger search: looking for similar peers who have the same experience (personas, David Ortiz)


Actionable Items:

Check out info on doppelgÃ_nger searches





Other Notes & Takeaways:

Audiobook

Title: The Beginning of Infinity: Explanations That Transform the World
Author: David Deutsch
My Review:
The Big Idea:

"Change accelerates change and weâ€™re moving toward self-reinforcing change that will go on for infinity. Correcting mistakes allows for progress, and stasis could only be preserved without error correction (therefore is immoral).

â€œThere is only one known phenomenon which, if it ever occurred, would have effects that did not fall off with distance, and that is the creation of a certain type of knowl- edge, namely a beginning of infinity. Indeed, knowledge can aim itself at a target, travel vast distances having scarcely any effect, and then utterly transform the destination.â€ù
"
Â 
Highlights:
Â 
â€œThe very existence of Athens, however peaceful, is a deadly threat to Spartaâ€™s stasis. And therefore, in the long run, the condition for the continued stasis of Sparta (which means its continued existence, as they see it) is the destruction of progress in Athens (which from our perspective would constitute the destruction of Athens).â€ù

â€œThe scientific revolution was part of a wider intellectual revolution, the Enlightenment, which also brought progress in other fields, especially moral and political philosophy, and in the institutions of society. Unfortunately, the term â€˜the Enlightenmentâ€™ is used by historians and philosophers to denote a variety of different trends, some of them violently opposed to each other. What I mean by it will emerge here as we go along. It is one of several aspects of â€˜the beginning of infinityâ€™, and is a theme of this book. But one thing that all conceptions of the Enlightenment agree on is that it was a rebellion, and specifically a rebellion against authority in regard to knowledge.â€ù

â€œSparta has no philosophers. Thatâ€™s because the job of a philosopher is to understand things better, which is a form of change, so they donâ€™t want it. Another difference: they donâ€™t honour living poets, only dead ones. Why? Because dead poets donâ€™t write anything new, but live ones do. A third difference: their education system is insanely harsh; ours is famously lax. Why? Because they donâ€™t want their kids to dare to question anything, so that they wonâ€™t ever think of changing anything.â€ù


Actionable Items:

Um

Uh

Reread maybe?

Other Notes & Takeaways:
Not sure what everyone who liked this was actually getting out of it.



Format Consumed:
Audiobook

Title: Sapiens: A Brief History of Humankind
Author: Yuval Noah Harari
My Review:
The Big Idea:

Thought provoking look at the history of humanity that roughly follows the evolutionary history of homo sapiens sapiens and highlights the inflection points of cognitive, agricultural, and scientific revolutions.
Â 
Highlights:
Â 
â€œEven worse, greedy bosses might curtail the workersâ€™ freedom of movement through debt peonage or slavery. At the end of the Middle Ages, slavery was almost unknown in Christian Europe. During the early modern period, the rise of European capitalism went hand in hand with the rise of the Atlantic slave trade. Unrestrained market forces, rather than tyrannical kings or racist ideologues, were responsible for this calamity.â€ù

This quote stuck with me most among many thoughts from this great book.

â€œThe Scientific Revolution has not been a revolution of knowledge. It has been above all a revolution of ignorance. The great discovery that launched the Scientific Revolution was the discovery that humans do not know the answers to their most important questions.â€œ

Such a beautiful analysis of the naturalist vs religious viewpoints"

"There is great discussion about the usefulness of untrue claims. The discussion of equality and the analysis of the Declaration of Independence were particularly thought provoking:

â€œAccording to the science of biology, people were not â€˜createdâ€™. They have evolved. And they certainly did not evolve to be â€˜equalâ€™. The idea of equality is inextricably intertwined with the idea of creation. The Americans got the idea of equality from Christianity, which argues that every person has a divinely created soul, and that all souls are equal before God. However, if we do not believe in the Christian myths about God, creation and souls, what does it mean that all people are â€˜equalâ€™?â€ù


Actionable Items:

Reread Sapiens





Other Notes & Takeaways:
This book seems like one where you should come back to it regularly to use in recalibration get thoughts about the world. Rereading seems like it would provide new insights each time.



Format Consumed:
Audiobook

â€œBut when we really delve into the reasons for why we canâ€™t let something go, there are only two: an attachment to the past or a fear for the future.â€ù

Title: Spark Joy: An Illustrated Master Class on the Art of Organizing and Tidying Up
Author: Marie KondÅç
My Review:
The Big Idea:

"Get rid of stuff that doesn't ""spark joy"" in your life. Systematically go through everything you own, and remove the extras. This book is the follow-up/best practices to ""The Life-Changing Magic of Tidying Up"" which I haven't yet read.
Parts are mumbo-jumbo, parts are spiritual twins to Getting Things Done. In the same vein as GTD, I expect to try the method when I have the time/headspace, and see what sticks. She's clearly thought alot about this tidying thing, and her experience seems worthy of leverage for our next spring-cleaning.

This definitely seems like a book better read than listened to."
Â 
Highlights:
Â 
â€œDiscarding is not the point; what matters is keeping those things that bring you joy. If you discard everything until you have nothing left but an empty house, I donâ€™t think youâ€™ll be happy living there. Our goal in tidying should be to create a living environment filled with the things we love.â€ù I like the idea of simplicity in this way.

â€œI want to live my life in such a way that it colors my things with memories.â€ù Adventure!

â€œHaving spent most of my life looking at things of every description, including those in my clientsâ€™ homes, I have discovered three common elements involved in attraction: the actual beauty of the object itself (innate attraction), the amount of love that has been poured into it (acquired attraction), and the amount of history or significance it has accrued (experiential value).â€ù


Actionable Items:

"Read ""The Life-Changing Magic of Tidying Up"""

Try the konmari method.

Fold clothes.

Other Notes & Takeaways:
"For a ""best practices"" book, I found surprisingly few ideas that stuck with me. I do want to try the konmari method when I get time though."

Title: Lean In: Women, Work, and the Will to Lead
Author: Sheryl Sandberg
My Review:
The Big Idea:

"The book was very focused on Leaning In to ones career, with a strong focus on the careers and lives of women in the 21st century. Through personal and narrative examples she tries to demonstrate how she thinks about work/life balnce, how careers are jungle gyms rather than ladders, and how we might find a future where women and men are not the same but are equal.

I donâ€™t know whether itâ€™s that sheâ€™s preaching to the choir and I already believe, a latent unrecognized sexism,Â or just a disconnect between her as a senior executive whoâ€™s been lucky and successful and the reality of most people, but this book was just OK to me. I started and stopped the audiobook a couple times, both due to the current political climate (I read this as the Weinstein/Hollywood/Policical sexual harrassment scandals were ramping up), and because I didn't feel compelled by the narrative.Â  I'm glad that I have experienced it, but I was hoping for something better and groundbreaking or truly thought provoking. Maybe my expectations were just too high. The things that stuck with me were smaller things that were less related to the main theme, but mostly this was an ok business memoir. "
Â 
Highlights:
Â 
"â€œLeadership is about making others better as a result of your presence and making sure that impact lasts in your absence.""
(Harvard Business School definition of leadership). This really stuck with me as a quality definition of Leadership, and one I directly aspire to emulate"

â€œCareers are a jungle gym, not a best parts of the book that aligned with the main theme were related to this.

â€œSuccess and likeability are positively correlated for men and negatively for women. When a man is successful, he is liked by both men and women. When a woman is successful, people of both genders like her less.â€ù I already groked this, which might be why much of the book fell flat for me.


Actionable Items:

Work on my own definition and process for receiving/giving mentoring

Actively solicit advice/request feedback

Manage my career/life, maybe set up Personal Board of Directors

Other Notes & Takeaways:
"Mentoring:
-Pointed questions, tailored to audience
-Do homework on who you are talking to and what you are asking
-Donâ€™t ask for a mentor, ask for specific help

Soliciting advice/requesting feedback:
-What can I do better?
-Commitment to Weekly feedback: allows boss/employee, mentor/mentee, coach/player to be aired and discussed quickly

Maternal gate keeping: mom telling dad what to do
"



Format Consumed:
Audiobook

Title: Grit
Author: Angela Duckworth
My Review:
The Big Idea

Success equals effort times skill. Skill equals talent times effort. Effort counts twice.

This book feels like it doesnâ€™t really deserve its own named theory. Itâ€™s a great book when building on other theories and providing examples, but itâ€™s at its worst when describing the development and process of the Grit theory itself. How is it different than Carol Dwekâ€™s Growth Mindset? She even mentions that in every avenue examined, Growth Mindset and Grit go together. Itâ€™s not really clear why other than so that she gets to put her name on the Theory. It seems that recent science (per wikipedia) bears out that there's little meaningful difference between Grit and Conscientiousness (from the Big 5 Traits)



Highlights

Authoritative parenting or coaching: supportive and demanding

Growth Mindset (especially as described in her west point stories) can be developed.

Will Smith: ridiculous work ethic "I will die on the treadmill"

treadmill test of grit

"Staying on the treadmill is one thing, and I do think itâ€™s related to staying true to our commitments even when weâ€™re not comfortable. But getting back on the treadmill the next day, eager to try again, is in my view even more reflective of grit. Because when you donâ€™t come back the next dayâ€”when you permanently turn your back on a commitmentâ€”your effort plummets to zero. As a consequence, your skills stop improving, and at the same time, you stop producing anything with whatever skills you have."



Actionable Items

Mcconahey: sweat for an hour a day / one sweat a day

Three-step process for prioritizing (from Warren Buffet):
â€¢ Write down your top 25 major/career goals on a single piece of paper.
â€¢ Put the top five on one list and the remaining 20 on a second list.
â€¢ Circle only your top five options. Do these.
â€¢ Look at the 20 things that you did not choose, and avoid them like the plague (at all costs).

The Hard Thing Rule
-everyone has to do a Hard Thing. Soccer/piano/job/etc.
-you can only quit at a logical stopping point; canâ€™t quit on a bad day
-you get to pick your Hard Thing

idea - one hard thing in 3 categories (a la Tim Ferriss while traveling)
-intellectual / language,
-social / team,
-kinesthetic / sport / martial art



Other Notes & Takeaways

Idea to ponder: ask for help

One story I think captures why I have a growth mindset even though I was permanent GATE in elementary and called smart: I enjoyed working to learn things, so rarely hit the wall of "I canâ€™t learn this" Format Consumed: Audiobook
